hackathon-eligibility: If you applied to PennApps XIV,
hackathon-rules: Only teams comprised wholly of eligible participants that submit their hacks to this DevPost, and then go on to demo their hack at the PennApps expo can win prizes.
hackathon-requirements: Make your project, submit your hack to Devpost and attend the PennApps expo to show off what you built. You
hackathon-description-header: Hacking for the Hack of It

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Oculus Rift + Apple Watch Sport/Android Wear + XBOX One/PS4; Lutron Plug-In Dimmer Kit; Travel Vouchers (from AirBnb). Winners will also be flown to Facebook headquarters for the Global Hackathon Finals.
Oculus Rift + Apple Watch Sport/Android Wear/XBOX One/PS4
Oculus Rift/Apple Watch Sport/Android Wear/XBOX One/PS4
Hacks that have applications in wellness, medicine and healthcare.
Hacks that have applications in education. Prizes: iPad Minis for each team member
Hacks where the main focus is on hardware. Prize: Hardware kits for each team member
Hacks where the main focus is on cybersecurity.
Hacks where the main focus is on Virtual/Augmented Reality.
Hacks with a primary goal geared towards issues of social or civic impact, or focus on a local community.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: PennApps Route | Best Social/Civic Hacking Hack Sponsored by JP Morgan

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Capital One. Winners will receive $400 Amazon gift cards each.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of the Capital One API - Nessie

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by NameCheap. Winners will receive $150 credit in their NameCheap accounts.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Domain Name Registered in PennApps XIV

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Qualtrics. Winner will receive their choice of a mountain bike, longboard, or snowboard.
Create an “out of the box” solution to be sold to a company. Presented by Blackstone. Each member of the winning team will receive a pair of ATH-M50x headphones.
Presented by Comcast NBCUniversal. Winners will receive Oculus Rifts.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of VR/AR for Content Discovery

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Given to the hack which demonstrates a good integration between hardware and software. Presented by Lutron. Winners will receive Lutron Caséta Wireless Smart Lighting Plug-in Lamp Dimmer Kits (HomeKit-enabled).

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Nexmo API - 2nd place

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Linode. Winners will receive Pebble watches.
Given to the best hack that uses the Aladdin API. Presented by BlackRock. Winners will receive drones.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Financial Hack Using the Aladdin API

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Given to the best hack that uses MongoDB as its database. Presented by MongoDB.
1 Pixel C Tablet + 2 Chromecasts + Android Plushies; Given to the two best Progressive Web Apps. Presented by Google & Polymer.
Presented by Goldman Sachs. Winners will receive Bose speakers.
$50 in 3D printing credit
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Rapid Prototyping, sponsored by AddLab

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Given to the hack that demonstrates the best use and/or design using PYNQ-Z1 board, overlay design, application. Presented by Xilinx Inc.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Design Using PYNQ-Z1 Boards, Peripherals, and Tools (3)

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Lyft. Winners will receive a Lyft backpack, $20 gift card, and an Amazon Echo each.
Presented by Taser. Each member of the winning team will receive a Parrot BEBOP2 drone.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Public Safety or Video Processing App

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Winning team gets Amazon Echos. Presented by Amazon.
Presented by L-3.
Awarded to the hack most likely to continue post-hackathon. Winners will receive an invitation to come to NY to pitch for 25k in funding from Rough Draft Ventures. Presented by Rough Draft Ventures.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Most Entrepreneurial Hack - Rough Draft Ventures

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=220 S 33rd St, Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Is the hack technically interesting or difficult? Is it just some lipstick on an API, or were there real technical challenges to surmount? This is the most important criterion that your hack will be judged upon for the general prizes.
Is the hack more than just another generic social/mobile/local app? Does it do something entirely novel, or at least take a fresh approach to an old problem?
Is the hack usable in its current state? Is the user experience smooth? Does everything appear to work? Is it well designed?
Is the hack practical? Is it something people would actually use? Does it fulfill a real need people have?
